text: Hitojichi shihō (, "hostage justice") is a Japanese-language phrase used in criticizing the Japanese judiciary. It refers to the period during which a defendant is held while denying an accusation, which is long compared with cases in which a defendant does not deny an accusation in Japanese criminal action procedure. Le Figaro reported that Carlos Ghosn's French lawyers described his continued Japanese detention in a complaint filed with the UNHCR as "hostage justice". CNN quoted Jeff Kingston, director of Asian studies at Temple University's Japan campus, stating "That system of hostage justice, I think, does not bear scrutiny.""Carlos Ghosn case puts Japan's system of 'hostage justice' under scrutiny", CNN ==See also== * Daiyō kangoku ==References== ==Further reading== * Category:Japanese words and phrases
title: Hitojichi shihō
